intent: Identity, authentication, authorization, and access governance principles for defensive reasoning and secure system design.

principles.name: Identity Is the New Perimeter
principles.summary: In modern systems, identity and access controls define trust boundaries more than network location.

principles.name: Strong Authentication
principles.summary: Authentication should rely on multiple factors and resistant methods (e.g., phishing-resistant MFA).
coreIdeas: Prefer hardware-based or app-based MFA over SMS when feasible.
Enforce strong password policies or passwordless models.

principles.name: Least Privilege & Role-Based Access
principles.summary: Users and systems should have only the permissions necessary to perform required tasks.
coreIdeas: Define roles clearly and avoid blanket admin access.
Use temporary privilege elevation where possible.

principles.name: Identity Lifecycle Management
principles.summary: Access rights must reflect employment status and role changes in real time.

controls.name: Account Activity Monitoring
controls.description: Monitor login attempts, privilege escalation, and anomalous access patterns.

controls.name: Secrets & Credential Management
controls.description: Protect and rotate API keys, tokens, and service credentials.
principles: Never hardcode secrets in source code.
Use secret vaults or secure storage.
Rotate credentials on a defined schedule.

riskPatterns.description: Phishing or malware leading to stolen credentials.
riskPatterns.impact: Account takeover, lateral movement, data exfiltration.

riskPatterns.description: User gains elevated permissions beyond intended scope.
riskPatterns.impact: Administrative control and potential systemic compromise.
